title: Beyond the breadline: Charitable food provision and survival strategies of the urban poor in a comparative perspective
descriptions:
**Title:** Comparative Analysis of Charitable Food Provision in Urban Contexts: A Multimethod Approach

**Abstract:**

Food charities play a vital role in mitigating urban food insecurity, particularly in the wake of diminishing welfare benefits and the growing imperative for sustainable food systems. Despite their widespread presence, existing research lacks a comprehensive framework for comparing and understanding Charitable Food Provision (CFP) across diverse urban and national contexts. This project proposes to address this knowledge gap through a comparative analysis of CFP in multiple countries and cities, focusing on Italy, Japan, and the Netherlands.

Using a combination of event sequence analysis, mixed-methods social network analysis, and urban ethnography, this study will chart the historical development of CFP, examine current dynamics and interrelationships between providers and authorities, and investigate the role of CFP in poor people's survival strategies. The research will also develop an innovative tool for real-time data collection on urban CFP dynamics. By crafting a comprehensive framework for CFP comparison, this project aims to contribute new knowledge across multiple disciplines, including urban studies, sustainability, organization studies, food studies, and social policy. The insights gained will have important implications for policymakers, practitioners, and scholars seeking to understand and address urban food insecurity.

While considerable research addresses food insecurity and support, the literature lacks a robust framework to understand and compare Charitable Food Provision (CFP) across countries and cities.
